newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Airlines slam night curbs at Amsterdam's Schiphol.
newsitem.headline: Airlines slam night curbs at Amsterdam's Schiphol.

text.p: Airlines operating out of Schiphol unanimously condemned tough new restrictions on night flights unveiled by Amsterdam's airport on Friday as "wholly unacceptable".

The curbs, aimed at keeping noise levels within legally determined limits, will ban night-time take-offs of most wide-body aircraft -- such as DC10s and Boeing 747 100s,200s and 300s and the Boeing 747SP -- from August 1.

The night ban -- from 2300 through 0600 hours -- will also apply to all flights running into delays which reach beyond the 2300 watershed, while unscheduled landings during night hours will be subject to penalty fines.
"We have no alternative if we are to remain within the legally defined noise limits," Schiphol president Hans Smits told a news conference to announce the measures.
The restrictions will particularly affect cargo carriers operating through Schiphol and, to a lesser extent, charter airlines, Smits said.

As a result Schiphol -- which handled some 1.3 million tonnes of goods in 1996 and boasted Europe's biggest annual cargo growth in May -- is expected to lose some 30,000 tonnes of cargo this year, rising to 50-100,000 tonnes in 1998.
Thousands of jobs in the cargo industry could go, Smits added.
But he said, "If we don't impose these restrictions now, the whole airport would have to be shut overnight from around September."
However, a spokesman for Dutch carrier KLM condemned the measures as "overkill", saying the curbs were "both operationally and commercially unacceptable."

As the proposals now stand, KLM would be forced to deploy alternative aircraft for three weekly cargo flights currently operated with low-noise so-called chapter three Boeing aircraft from U.S carrier Atlas Air, spokesman Peter Offerman said.
But KLM was more worried about the blanket ban on unscheduled night departures given the many flights it operated out of Schiphol just prior to the watershed, Offerman said.

"We operate a lot of flights between 10 and 11 pm using MD-11s and 747-400s. According to the letter of the Schiphol proposal, we would not be allowed to take off in the event of a limited delay," he said. "The measures are far too rigid."
He said KLM will submit a counter-proposal to the traffic ministry seeking an exemption for chapter three aircraft.
"We believe a ban which excludes chapter three aircraft will enable Schiphol to keep within the statutory noise threshold," Offerman said.
Israel's El Al and privately-owned Polar Air will also be badly hit by the measures, as will Martinair, KLM's 50-50 freight and passenger joint venture with Rotterdam's Nedlloyd.
El Al is now mulling the transfer of its cargo hub to Belgium's Liege airport, and Martinair has criticised the proposed measures as discriminatory and unfair.
"The three Boeing 747 aircraft operated by Martinair are so-called chapter three aircraft...of the most low-noise," it said in a statement.
"Excluding Martinair chapter three aircraft while allowing aircraft from other airlines which fall into the same category is unreasonable and, in Martinair's view, unacceptable," the airline said.
Martinair said its night-time flight movements had remained constant over the last three years and as such it had not contributed to the capacity bottleneck.

But Smits said Schiphol's failure to agree a voluntary 50 percent reduction in night-time take-offs with the airlines concerned meant it had been forced to impose a unilateral ban which affected the culpable and non-culpable alike.
Some 70 percent of Schiphol's annual quota of night flights had already been used up, Smits said.
This was due mainly to greater-than-envisaged deployment of noisy wide-body aircraft and the use of Hercules craft for charter and freight, he said.

He said Schiphol had requested urgent talks with transport minister Annemarie Jorritsma in a bid to resolve the problem of noise restrictions which will effectively limit further airport growth to "a few percent" over the coming years.
